*Summary of Steve’s Key Points*
1. *Staging Site Overwrite:*
    ◦ Steve *overwrote the staging site* with the *production site* today.
    ◦ This means the *staging environment now mirrors production*, including the same login credentials.
2. *Plugins and Licensing:*
    ◦ Some *WordPress plugins* may not function fully in staging because they *lack additional environment licenses*.
    ◦ That could result in *limited functionality or error messages*, but it _shouldn't affect your work_.
3. *API Connections:*
    ◦ *Staging uses PRODUCTION APIs*, so any testing done there could impact live systems.
    ◦ Be *mindful of this when testing*—only GA4 and a few others might be excluded.
4. *Test vs Staging:*
    ◦ There's a separate "test" environment that *isn't being overwritten*.
    ◦ Steve prefers you to work in *staging*, since he can reset it easily, and wants to keep "test" unchanged for now.
5. *Communication:*
    ◦ He's happy to chat via *email* or *Microsoft Teams*—whichever is faster for you during setup.
6. *Access Info:*
    ◦ The *staging site is now live* and password protected.
• Access details:
        ▪︎ Website: <https://trupanionstg.wpenginepowered.com>
        ▪︎ Gate username: `trupanionstg`
        ▪︎ Gate password: ********* (lastpass)
        ▪︎ Admin login: <https://trupanionstg.wpenginepowered.com/wp-admin>
    ◦ Use the *admin login credentials* previously provided (not included in this email) after passing the gate.

*Access Checklist:*
• GA4 - received
• Google Tag Manager - received
• Google Ads - received but our limit has been reached so need to request from them
• Wordpress Admin Access 
*Overall Scope:*

*Tracking Audit (Week 1)*
• Review GA4 setup 
• Audit Google Tag Manager (GTM) configuration and event tracking
• Evaluate existing event tagging and misattribution issues (e.g., quote form conflation, unassigned traffic)
• Identify misattribution or gaps in tracking, especially:
    ◦ Quote journey steps
    ◦ Activation journey
    ◦ Call-to-action buttons
    ◦ Unassigned traffic causes
*Tracking Fixes and Improvements Implementation (Week 2 to 3)*
• Configure server-side tagging via *<http://Stape.io|Stape.io>*, including:
    ◦ Stape container and subdomain setup
    ◦ Integration with GA4 via server container
    ◦ Integration with Google Ads (and optionally Meta, if relevant)
• Implement of Code Changes to push required events to the DataLayer
• Migrate key events from client-side to server-side GTM where applicable:
    ◦ Quote form submissions
    ◦ Activation steps
    ◦ Conversion events
• Ensure proper user and session attribution (mitigating "unassigned" traffic)
• 
*Recommendations & Documentation (Week 3)*
• Document the fixes and GTM/GA4 configurations
• Recommend future enhancements for server-side tracking and potential A/B testing strategies

<@U02V24EQ6R4>
 Here’s a much clearer picture of the current setup and what I recommend:

*Google Analytics 4:*
*TL;DR:* The events we’re seeing in GA4 are _not_ just coming from the Google Tag Manager container we have access to.
• There are *custom events* set up _directly_ within GA4 (see screenshot #1 for reference).
• I’ve identified *two GTM containers* on the site (screenshot #2):
    ◦ `GTM-NLZTZRKF` – this is the one *we’re actively using* for tracking.
    ◦ `GTM-5P79ND2` – this one *we don’t have access to* and *aren’t using*.
We’re already tracking everything we need using `GTM-NLZTZRKF`.

*Google Ads:*
I made the final GTM updates on *June 11, 2025*.
The discrepancy between Google Ads and GA4 conversions is gradually decreasing. I’ll continue to monitor and share more data, but here are the current numbers:
• *June 12*
    ◦ Google Ads: 69
    ◦ GA4: 48
• *June 13*
    ◦ Google Ads: 25
    ◦ GA4: 26
*Recommendation:*
Since the client is unsure about what to track and has given us the freedom to decide, I suggest the following:
• *Remove* all existing _custom event setups_ within GA4 that aren’t linked to our GTM implementation.
• *Disable or remove* the second GTM container (`GTM-5P79ND2`) from the site.
That way, the only events flowing into GA4 will be the ones we explicitly track via `GTM-NLZTZRKF`, ensuring full control and consistency. Let me know what you think.

*Trupanion Email Draft:*

Hi Josephine,

Thank you for bringing this to our attention.

I checked with our developer, and we did make a small update to a file related to API handling on Friday, June 27th. The change involved pushing tracking information to the *dataLayer* during the final step of the quote process. This was solely intended to enhance analytics tracking and did not touch the breed dropdown or any other input fields. Everything was tested after deployment and appeared to be functioning as expected.

That said, we understand the issue you encountered occurred around the same time. While we don’t believe our update directly caused it, we recognize that something may have inadvertently slipped through.

Since we don’t have access to server logs, it’s challenging to confirm the root cause from our side. That said, we’re more than happy to assist in your investigation however we can. Please let us know if there’s anything specific you’d like us to look into.
